qas.question: What did Reformers increase so that their followers could read the Bible?
In the middle of the eighteenth century, how many Swedes could read and write?

answers.text: eight of ten men and women

qas.question: What state became a hub of learning?

context: As the Reformers wanted all members of the church to be able to read the Bible, <a0_0>education<a0_0/> on all levels got a strong boost. By the middle of the eighteenth century, the literacy rate in England was about 60 per cent, in Scotland 65 per cent, and in Sweden <a1_0>eight of ten men and women<a1_0/> were able to read and to write. Colleges and universities were founded. For example, <a2_0>the Puritans<a2_0/> who established Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1628 founded Harvard College only eight years later. About a dozen other colleges followed in the 18th century, including Yale (<a3_0>1701<a3_0/>). <a4_0>Pennsylvania<a4_0/> also became a centre of learning.
